headline.main: Let's Try Again on Health Care

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Toward Universal Coverage'' (editorial, Sept. 24):

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to allow imports of low-priced prescription drugs won support from House Republican leaders today, making it all but certain that Congress and President Clinton could eventually agree on the legislation. Although the pharmaceutical industry has lobbied furiously against the measure, the House Republican leaders announced that they would approve the Senate-passed version of the bill, which Mr. Clinton also supports. Their decision to make the bill a priority, just six weeks before the elections, suggests how potent the cost of prescription drugs has become as a political issue.

headline.main: Accord Likely on Measure Allowing Drug Imports

docs.abstract: Rep Dick Armey says House Republican leaders will approve Senate-passed version of Sen James M Jeffords bill to allow re-imports of American-made prescription drugs from nations where they are sold at far lower prices; bill is backed by Pres Clinton and opposed by drug industry; bill's impact on drug prices will be delayed for about two years, while Food and Drug Administration writes rules to implement law; bill includes safeguards to protect consumers (M)

byline.original: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: AL GORE Remarks from a speech on Medicare policy yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla.: ''There is a real debate in this election over the future of Medicare. And I think it's an important debate. The other side has called Medicare a 'government H.M.O.' They really never have liked it. They've suggested that you shouldn't trust Medicare to provide prescription drug coverage. Let me tell you: Medicare has been a lifeline for tens of millions of families. It's given millions the choice of doctors and health plans so they don't have to choose between health care and food and rent. So I'll take Medicare over the real H.M.O.'s any day of the week.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from remarks on Medicare policy by Vice Pres Al Gore in St Petersburg, Fla (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: If a child at the Enrico Fermi School in Yonkers is found to have attention deficit disorder, parents can choose an unusual alternative to medication: neurofeedback, a computerized biofeedback system that some say strengthens the brain. Linda Vergara, the school's principal, said she decided to try the approach when doctors diagnosed the disorder in her son in 1992. ''They told me I needed to give him something to calm him down,'' she said.

headline.main: Some See Hope in Biofeedback for Attention Disorder

docs.abstract: Some parents whose child is found to have attention deficit disorder can choose unusual alternative to medication: neurofeedback, a computerized biofeedback system that some say strengthens brain; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last month, New Jerseyans have hardly been able to avoid hearing about the virtues of Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic multimillionaire who has spent more than $1 million a week on television advertising for his Senate campaign. With only six weeks to go before the November election, his underfinanced Republican opponent, Representative Bob Franks, has yet to broadcast a single commercial. Yesterday, however, a Washington group that has ties to moderate Republicans like Gov. Christine Todd Whitman came to Mr. Franks's rescue with a radio ad criticizing his rival's recent missteps on the campaign trail. The group paying for the ad, the Republican Leadership Council, said it would broadcast more radio and television advertisements in the next few weeks to help defeat Mr. Corzine.

headline.main: Republican Group Buys Radio Ad on Behalf of Bob Franks

docs.abstract: Republican Leadership Council to pay for radio advertisement for Repr Robert Franks, who is seeking US Senate seat from New Jersey; his opponent, Jon S Corzine, receives help from New Jersey Citizen Action when they criticize Franks for his record on several important issues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More companies are offering health insurance benefits to partners of gay and lesbian employees than ever before, including more than 100 of the Fortune 500 companies, a new study has found. As of August, 3,572 companies, colleges, universities, states and local governments were offering or had announced that they would offer health insurance coverage to domestic partners of their employees -- an increase of 25 percent from last year, the study found. In August 1999, 2,856 of these companies, educational institutions and governments offered such benefits.
docs.abstract: Human Rights Campaign reports that more companies than ever are offering health insurance benefits to partners of gay and lesbian employees, including more than 100 of Fortune 500 comapnies; says employers have discovered that these benefits help attract and keep the best workers, a critical consideration in the current tight job market (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Concern About Earnings Continues to Hobble Stocks Stock prices slipped again, pulled down by continued worries about coming earnings reports from big technology companies.
docs.snippet: Concern About Earnings Continues to Hobble Stocks  Stock prices slipped again, pulled down by continued worries about coming earnings reports from big technology companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Campaigning in Florida, where as many as 40 percent of this November's voters may be 60 or older, Vice President Al Gore promised today to strengthen sanctions against health maintenance organizations that pull out of the Medicare market and to eliminate Medicare copayments and deductibles for a variety of preventive tests. Mr. Gore unveiled those proposals in a speech in St. Petersburg that opened a weeklong discussion of Medicare policy, an issue that is particularly potent in Florida. Before flying here to attend several fund-raisers, Mr. Gore used his speech to convey his stark differences on the issue with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, a comparison that illustrates the broader philosophical differences between the two campaigns. Along those lines, Mr. Gore also drew attention to a five-year-old interview in which Mr. Bush expressed support for the deep Medicare cuts championed by former House Speaker Newt Gingrich.

headline.main: Bush Would Use Medicare For Tax Cuts, Gore Says

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore campaigns in St Petersburg, Fla, where he promises to strenghten sanctions against health maintenance organizations that pull out of Medicare market and to eliminate copayments and deductibles for variety of preventive tests; says plans advocated by Gov George W Bush would take money out of Medicare for tax cuts for wealthy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: AIDS PROTESTERS ARRESTED Eleven people demonstrating against what they called inadequate housing and other city services for people with AIDS chained themselves around a pillar yesterday inside the Human Resources Administration building in Lower Manhattan. The police arrested them, charging one with criminal trespass and the others with criminal trespass and resisting arrest. The agency did not immediately return a call seeking comment. (NYT)
